course.subject: COMP
course.name: Practicing Cybersecurity: Attacks and Counter-measures
course.description: This course equips students with cybersecurity knowledge and current IT practices on security risk management. Through hands-on laboratory sessions, students will understand existing IT security issues, learn how to assess IT security risks, and conduct experiments on ethical hacking. They will practice system attack and defense strategies using security tools, so as to gain practical experience to become a cybersecurity professional. The course covers current security trends, industrial practices on IT security, design requirements for secure web and mobile applications, security assessment, risk analysis and risk management. Knowledge in web programming and database administration is not essential but a plus.
course.prerequisites: COMP 2012 OR COMP 2012H

reviews.author: smallpotato tom
reviews.title: As course title states: "Practical", but "Hard"
reviews.comment_content:
Very fruitful and comprehensive, but quite hard to understand all the things.

Week 1: Introduction to Cyber Security
- Set up virtualization environments like Azure Cloud Lab, AWS and CSE VM

Week 2: Virtualization and Network, WiFi Security and Encryption
- Analyze network activities, PCAP
- WiFi cracking

Week 3: Network Basics
- Set up AWS for web server

Week 4: Network Security and Attack
- Introduce vulnerability scanning tool, Nessus

Week 5: Web Application Programming
- Develop a simple web application using HTML, PHP and SQL

Week 6: Web Application Hacking
- Introduce common web application vulnerabilities

Week 7: OS System Security
- Privilege escalation and introduce Netcat

Week 8: IAM, Authentication and Authorization
- Password cracking, access control security and 2FA

Week 9: Application and Software Security
- Use buffer overflow to override authentication

Week 10: Network Security Defense Mechanisms
- VPN, AWS Network Security Group and Snort IDS

Week 11: Incident Handling and Web Log Analysis
- Introduce Elasticsearch and analyse Apache log
reviews.comment_teaching:
In this semester, we had lessons in Zoom.

Ricci was a good guy and had passion, though, his tone was really too boring.

Lecture notes and actual teaching content had great difference. He liked to mention some concepts that did not exist in the lecture notes or lab when he saw some wordings on the notes (these concepts even appeared in the final exam). The most challenging thing was, it's not possible to concentrate on the 4-hour lessons all the time (lecture+lab), so probably some important concepts could be missed.

Lecture notes and lab were not well designed too. The key content and relatively less important information were not balanced in the lecture notes. The instruction, requirement and questions in the lab were not clear enough.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
1. Lab work - 30%
2. Attendance (Required to attend all) - 10%
3. Two written assignments - 10%
4. Group presentation - 20%
5. Final exam (online quiz, open notes) - 30%

Mine:
99% in lab work,
full marks in attendance and written assignments,
group presentation slightly above mean,
final exam above mean ~10 marks,
got an A.

Ricci gave 10-15 students A range, and I actually did not master all the things. Fortune is really important.

But the grading is still quite good to me.
reviews.comment_workload:
No midterm, but the workload was still quite heavy for me.

Weekly 4-hour lecture+lab really, really tortured us.

We could have few days to finish each lab work, but they were not easy.

2 assignments counted only 10% for the grade but they consumed a lot of time.

The instruction and requirement for group presentation were not clear. Although it's officially called "project", it's more likely a "paper referencing assignment", but in group.

Like other people stated, the final online canvas exam was a nightmare. Although it's open book, it's just a game of Google + fortune. Questions were shuffled. MC and short questions were mixed. We could not return to the previous questions once we went ahead. Time limit, of course, was not enough for many people.

But if you have friends, many troubles can be solved (for the lab and assignments) :D

reviews.title: Really think twice before you register
reviews.comment_content:
The course includes these things in each week (number represents the week):

1. Basic concepts on IT Security / Setup VM environment
2. CentOS VM / Kali Linux / WiFi analysis and cracking / Wireshark / Virtual network
3. DNS / LAN and WAN / Directory services / SSL TLS / POODLE / WWW and FTP
4. Nmap scanning / sniffing / DoS attack / DNS info searching / Email attacks
5. PHP / HTML / CSS / Javascript / SQL / Web authentication / MySQL
6. OWASP 2017 top 10 attacks (teach 3 only, SQL injection / XSS / CSRF) / Web session management
7. System and kernel attack / patch management / Metasploit / reverse shell
8. IAM / Authentication / Authorization / Password cracking / Federated Auth.
9. Application security / Buffer overflow / Application firewall / secure code review / malware and virus
10. Network defense mechanisms / firewall / IDS / honeypot / VPN / Snort
11. Log analysis with Elastic Search / Kibana / Attack tracing

WoW, I cannot imagine a student can master all of them within ONE SEMESTER! The content is so rich, I suggest you to better think twice before you study this course as you must suffer if you did not learn half of them before. Despite the content is very useful, it is a bit too much.

Also, the technology used in some lessons are awful. Like the others said, PHP 5.4... I also don't know why I should use 2 hours to complete several html pages and write CSS in my Lab 5. It is a security course...

reviews.author: TrebledJ
reviews.title: A holistic survey of vocational cybersecurity skills
reviews.comment_content:
If you're looking for hands-on stuff, you'll be disappointed in this course, except for the few labs on basic web attacks and binary attacks. Why disappointed? Because the majority of the course focuses on a high-level view, utilising offensive Kali tools (which automate a lot of the hacking process) and defensive tools (which automate a lot of the filtering and protection).

Me? I already experienced hands-on attacks and fun in the Firebird CTF courses (COMP2633-4633). But cyber reality is far from just CTFs. Hence, I took this course to get a holistic understanding of attacks and countermeasures, learn Kali hacking tools, and familiarise myself with Windows. (Note one of the keywords in my title: vocational.) A lot of enterprise machines use Windows, and I haven't used Windows in a decade, so the opportunity to use Windows again was nice.

Seriously, if you want to have fun with cyberattacks and mess around with vulnerabilities, I suggest taking 2633-4633 instead of this course. It's much more rewarding, exhilarating, and addicting. The “hacking” labs of 4632 are a joke compared to what you learn in 2633-4633 (assuming you put in effort, ofc).

Those who are saying "oh 4632 bad because PHP old and yuck" are missing the point. Technology constantly evolves—no surprise. What you take out of this course shouldn't be the specific technology, but the underlying processes, reasoning, and attitude. Like- why do you think they teach C++ in 201X and not Python? Because pointers; raw, efficient algorithms, stripped of any garbage collection or automated process; low-levelness. Do you know how inefficient GitHub's markdown emoji picker is on long lines of text?

Also don't focus on the version and tool that much. Do you think the C++11 they teach is enough for jobs? Companies are using C++17 now, and C++23 is around the corner. And the libraries/tools—Boost, Qt, clang, CMake—those are also useful. One of my friends, who has been using Flutter for a long time once complained: "Haiyah, version updated. Need to learn so many things again." So don't get hung up on the tech. Focus on the processes and underlying (or err... overarching) things instead.

Side note, and back to PHP: this was the first time I played with a traditional pure server-side language (well, Python Flask doesn't count here), so it was an interesting experience learning how it works and seeing how crappy its documentation and vulnerabilities truly are. Come to think of it, a lot of server side software (Flask, Django, etc.) are based on the same principle of substitutions and evaluations. I suppose another benefit of learning old tech is being able to critique it more precisely by understanding its flaws.

Thanks for reading my rant.

Syllabus hasn't changed; see other reviews.

One thing they don't cover in the syllabus are modern cybersecurity vectors: blockchain/web3, AI, IoT. These were covered by group presentations though, so props to the groups that went there.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I won't discuss much here. A large portion was taught to me by our good friends Google and ChatGPT.

I only listened half-heartedly to Ricci's lectures while I worked on the labs. Ricci is nice though. Raises awareness of cybersecurity, recent cybersecurity news, and different fields (although biased towards forensics, i.e. his company/research). He takes time to answer our questions and prods us to think further (esp. during after-class questions).

One of the TAs delivered well. If you know, you know. The other TAs... well... they could improve.

To echo a few points:

- TAs don't prepare well for labs unless it's their assigned lab. So make sure to ask for the right TA.
- Sometimes asking the people around you is more effective than asking TAs. Don't hesitate lah.

So don't (solely) rely on TAs.

Also, the lab/hw marking is rather lazy. Feedback is ambiguous, and that’s *if* they give any feedback at all. Dropping this from an A to a B.
reviews.comment_grading:
I'll just echo and mention a few things.

- No exemplars of successful assignments after grading; except from friends who got full marks.
- Some deductions on lab work aren't commented on. You're left to guess what went wrong.
- Fair overall, but could be more transparent.
reviews.comment_workload:
Labs are taxing and occasionally overrun.

The exam was very challenging, but pretty fun. Wish we had more time to complete it properly.

Group presentation mechanics were... interesting. We're asked to record a 20-minute video of our presentation and submit it prior to presentation day. Makes sense, due to time constraints. Most groups just played their video, so it was quite chill.

reviews.author: JustChill
reviews.title: An extreme waste of time
reviews.comment_content:
There are other posts that listed the course content so I will skip them. But I have to add on the professor always spent tons of time talking about unrelated stuff and I am feeling a complete waste of time sitting in the class.

Although I can see that the prof has the heart to promote the field of cybersecurity, the course is executed in the worst possible way and almost every aspect of this course is a complete failure. It became torture for me to go to the class every Friday. (But I still have to go because of the attendance requirement) I think students will feel much better if they just take some online courses to learn cybersecurity instead of joining this course.

THANK YOU prof for ruining my interest in cybersecurity. Before I join the class, I have an interest to work in the cybersecurity field and I would like to learn more about it. But after joining this class, I HATE cybersecurity.

*警世* If you would like to learn more about cybersecurity, PLEASE just take some online courses and do not register for this course. I had a genuine interest in cybersecurity so I choose not to trust the review on USTSpace before and registered for this course but I FXXKING REGRET my decision.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Extremely boring tone.  

Also, the lecturer has extremely poor time management skills. The normal lecture time including the lab is 10:30-2:20. However, it overran almost every time, and there was a time when he finished the class at 3 pm. In my personal situation, I had another class at 3 pm, which meant that I did not have any time to grab some food for lunch, and I had to suffer from extreme hunger until my other class ended every Friday.

The professor may defend himself by saying that we can actually leave the classroom earlier and watch the Zoom lecture video afterward. However, please be noted that the quality of the Zoom video is extremely poor. Sometimes the screen shown on the Zoom video did not match the content. This may be caused by the fact that the Prof/TA only shared the screen of one of the applications but forgot to switch the screen sharing in Zoom when they were using other applications. This led to the fact that I can only listen to the recording, but I am not able to see what the Prof/TA is actually doing on the screen. Moreover, the soundtrack of the Zoom video is also of extremely poor quality. Sometimes the prof walked away and talked to the entire class, but the Zoom video could only vaguely record his sound. I could not hear what he said entirely when he walked away from the mic.

You may say that this is a face-to-face class, so it is normal that the quality of the Zoom video is poor. So, because of the poor quality of the video, I have to sit in the class physically until the class ends so that I can understand the course material.

I strongly suggest that if the lecturer still insists to hold this course next year, either the course should start at 8/9 am so that students can enjoy their lunch after the class or it should start at 12/1 pm after everyone finished their lunch. Also, you should put in the class descriptions saying that “It is expected that there will be huge delays in the class time, so please do not arrange another class or activities right after this class”. In my situation, I still have a 40mins gap so at least I can give up my lunch to attend the class. But what if other people have something to do at 2:30 pm?

Furthermore, most of the TA are extremely unknowledgeable. Most of the time, only one of the TA has prepared for the lab beforehand. The other TA did not understand the lab and was not able to answer my questions during lab time.

I want to put teaching grade Z. E is not low enough.
reviews.comment_grading: To be fair, I did not get my final grade for the course yet. So, no comments for this part for now.
reviews.comment_workload:
One lab each week including the add-drop period
Physical attendance required every week including the add-drop period
WTF? "Ricci, do you know what is the meaning of the Add-drop period?"

Moreover, the grading of the lab exercises is extremely slow. Today is 25/4 already but I still have not yet received my grade for my lab exercise for lab 6 which was due on 15/3. I understand that the prof has his own company so he is probably very busy. But if I didn’t receive the feedback on my lab exercise timely, how can I learn and improve properly? I probably had forgotten what I have wrote after such a long time. Also, for the assignment, the prof only released the grades but did not mention why my mark got deducted and where I did wrong. The prof also did not release any model answers so how can I learn from my mistakes when I don’t even know what did I do wrong?
